New Records: England are the first men's team in history to hold both the 50-over and 20-over World Cups simultaneously.
Key Match Events: Sam Curran's 3 for 12 from his four overs helped contain Pakistan to 137 for 8.
An unbeaten fifty from Ben Stokes sealed victory by five wickets with one over to spare.
Mohammad Wasim found an inside edge off Moeen Ali onto leg stump in the penultimate over.
An injury to Shaheen Shah Afridi ruled him out of the Pakistan attack, having bowled just 2.1 overs.
Stokes targeted Iftikhar, hitting boundaries to close in on the target.
Shaheen Afridi hobbled off the field due to injury.
Rauf dismissed Buttler, causing a pivotal moment in the match.
Shaheen Afridi bowled Alex Hales with a full ball.
Adil Rashid bowled a maiden over and took the wicket of Babar Azam.
Pakistan collapsed, losing wickets quickly towards the end of their innings.
Sam Curran dismissed Shan Masood with a strategic field placement.
Rashid bowled slower than usual, making it difficult for Pakistan to score.
Rashid dismissed Babar Azam with a googly.
Shan Masood attacked Livingstone, scoring 16 runs in an over.
Chris Woakes used slower balls, but they were less effective.
Sam Curran dismissed Mohammad Rizwan early in the innings.
Pre-Game Insights: Jos Buttler explained England chose to bowl due to weather concerns.
Babar Azam mentioned the historical significance of the 1992 World Cup.
England were unchanged, with Jordan and Salt keeping their places.
Pakistan fans hoped for a repeat of the 1992 World Cup victory.
Post-Match Reflections: Ben Stokes saw England home with 52 not out, six years after the Kolkata heartbreak.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The match was played at the Melbourne Cricket Ground.
The weather conditions were dry, improving the prospects of play.
The MCG posed different challenges compared to the semi-final venues.
